Blog.post: Following is an excerpt from an article by Randolph T. Holhut: Dan Kennedy, the media critic of the Boston Phoenix, pulled this telling nugget from Bill Clinton's autobiography, "My Life". In the passage, Clinton tells about a conversation he had with former Wyoming senator Alan Simpson regarding the political leanings of the press. "You know", Simpson said, "before you (Clinton) were elected, we Republicans believed most of the press was liberal. Now we have a more sophisticated view. They are liberal in a way. Most of them voted for you, but they think more like your right-wing critics do, and that's much more important... Democrats like you...get into government to help people. The right-wing extremists don't think government can do much to improve human nature, but they do like power. So does the press. And since you're president, they both get power the same way, by hurting you. In other words, on social hot-button issues such as same-sex marriage, abortion rights and gun control - issues that ultimately aren't that important in the larger scheme of things - there is a liberal bias in the corporate press. On the important issues, such as the economy and the national security state, the corporate press sits squarely on the right. And, to counteract the perennial cry of liberal bias by conservatives, the corporate press goes out of its way to attack liberal politicians. Randolph T. Holhut has been a journalist in New England for more than 20 years. He edited "The George Seldes Reader" (Barricade Books). He can be reached at randyholhut@yahoo.com . I'm sure we're all absorbed in the Democratic National Convention, but I wanted to share an observation about the whole "e-voting" issue. As you're probably aware, the problem with e-voting machines is that they don't provide an audit trail and are very easily "hacked"... It's already happened in California. What you may NOT , however, be aware of is the fact that the "preferred" e-voting machine is made by a company called Diebold . Another point of interest is that the owner of Diebold (a privately held company) is a HUGE supporter of the Bush Regime (both financially and in ideology). The "logic" forwarded by Diebold for not allowing computer scientists access to their code is that it would violate their "intellectual property" rights. This is a thinly veiled way of saying, "Forget it! You simply have to TRUST that we wouldn't manipulate results." (These machines are to be used in Florida... So much for trust and/or a fair election!) Diebold has also said that it isn't possible or practical to design the machines so they will produce a paper audit trail. This is where it gets really scary... I was running a little short on cash the other day and, like we all do, headed to the nearest ATM for a quick infusion of green backs. I inserted my card, entered my code, selected withdraw, entered the amount. POOF! Just like that, money came out of the machine. THEN, it asked me if I would like to make another transaction. I said no, and it asked me if I wanted a RECEIPT. I said, YES, and it spit out a piece of paper with x's over all but the last portion of my account number (to identify that, yes, I had indeed accessed funds from MY account), the amount I withdrew and my current balance. NOTE: I did this at an ATM that isn't affiliated with my bank, and STILL got this information... As I was preparing to drive off, the manufacturer's name on the machine hit me like a ton of bricks! DIEBOLD Now, I'm not always the sharpest knife in the drawer but this one's a real no-brainer that even Gomer Pyle could understand! If DIEBOLD can make an ATM that can access, process and supply all this information, why in the world can't they make their voting machines do the same thing??? Could it be because they don't WANT them TO??? You decide.

OK, so whether you're in favor or opposed to this whole notion of "gay marriage", the Republican arm of our government (not just the Congress but I'll include our Pretender-In-Chief in this, too) are now pissing and moaning about the "radical justices" overstepping their bounds. They use this logic to, in effect, castrate the judicial system. Last time I read the Constitution, there was a reason for THREE (not 2) branches of government. It's called checks and balances, Mr. Shrub. SO, perhaps Bush&Co. should brush up on the Constitution, instead of using it as so much Charmin. There are a couple of problems with this failed Amendment... FIRST and foremost, the notion that it even made it out of committee is frightening! What's up with that? Poor delusional John Cornyn thinking that Constitutionally legislating morality into the Constitution would just make the GLBT community go rushing back into our cramped little closests like so many roaches when the lights are turned on! SECOND, those "radical justices" legislating from the bench are doing their jobs! It's up to each branch of the government to keep the others in line (or at least provide a modicum of fairness!). The radical right is tramping so many sour grapes on this one! If the courts were in agreement with them (think the Supremes annointing Shrub to the throne), they would be putting them on a pedestal of piety. THIRD and most important, our Constitution has never been used to limit rights, but only to expand them. Think women's suffrage, a woman's right to choose, the abolishment of slavery, Civil Rights for ethnic and gender minorities, the legal voting age being established at 18. Now, the House has lost its collective mind (following on the heels of the Senate) with its "Marriage Protection Act" which passed 233-to-194. This Act would bar federal courts from hearing challenges to parts of the DOMA (a piece of bad legislation in itself, even if Clinton DID sign it). I'll save "Civil Rights for ethnic and gender minorities" for another upcoming rant.

Following is an excerpt from an article by Molly Ivins that I found at urlLink www.thesmirkingchimp.com (which is one of my favorite web sites, by the way): "For the first two days I was on this media marathon, the story du jour was the Senate Intelligence Committee report that concluded the CIA was just flat wrong on its pre-war calls on Iraq. Wrong abut the weapons of mass destruction, wrong about connections to Al Qaeda, wrong about Saddam Hussein having a nuclear program and so on. All of which we already knew the government had been wrong about, but this was the Official Report.So here's the Republican reaction: "See, the CIA was wrong, so you people owe President Bush an apology." I'm sitting there, brilliantly riposting, "Huh?" Here's the chain of logic. The CIA was wrong, therefore those on the left who say President Bush lied to us are wrong because he wasn't lying, he just believed the CIA. And you people are being rude and hateful and ugly and just mean about President Bush, and we want an apology.What I'm worried about here is the amnesia factor. Am I the only person around who distinctly remembers an entire 18 months ago? This is what happened: The CIA was wrong, but it wasn't wrong enough for the White House, which kept pushing the spies to be much wronger. The CIA's lack of sufficient wrongness was so troubling to the anxious Iraq hawks that they kept touting their own reliable sources, such as Ahmad Chalabi and his merry crew of fabulists. The neo-cons even set up their very own little intelligence shop in the Pentagon to push us into this folly in Iraq."
